person.note: For the form אמבי see vol. 4, under Ambi (1) S-H/F, p. 412. On the interchange of י and ו see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.1, p. 18.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
Because so many other inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is possible to date the undated ones approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
This is a straightforward transliteration of the name, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11.
In Greek – ἀπαθανάντας ἐτῶν κη ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
The inscription is dated to 305 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1.1.
The reading is mine. The editors refrained from suggesting onesee previous note. On the interchange of the feminine α and η suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3, pp. 12-13
Jewishness indicated by the word (in Jewish characters) ום[של], see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 33.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
For this form see vol. 1, under Imma (7) S-H/F, p. 419.
In the Golan.
See above, n. 5.
The amulet was obviously written by a Jew, but the client need not have been one, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.7, p. 37.
In Hebrew – יתומה.On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.7.3.
This could be a name but it could be short for [מעשה] בילדה ([A story] about a girl), see previous note, in which case it is no name.
She is a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
North of Jericho.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
On the fall of the י as scribal error, or a reflection of another dialect see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.4, p. 13.
The inscription is dated to 435 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the Golan, north east of the Sea of Galilee.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
She is the sister of Judah (10) the Patriarch who was in office at the time of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
The inscription is dated to 362 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
The inscription is dated to 291 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
For this form see vol. 1, under Mara (2) S-H/F, p. 422.

In Greek – Θαλεθθι Μαρα θυγάτηρ Σαμουήλ γυνὴ Λε[οντίου]. According to Lifschitz “Θαλεθθιest sans doute la transcription grecque du mot araméen talitha.” But he concedes that Talitha could also be a proper name.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3 Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. Tiberias was mostly populated by Jews, but not exclusively, see Introduction 6.2.1.5.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

So in BS2:66. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Both forms are found on the epitaphs. Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1.1.
So in BS2:68, see previous note.
In Greek – ἱηρείας. On this title see vol. 1, under Megiste (1) G/F, p. 322 and vol. 3, under Marin (8) S-H/F, p. 684.
This is the tear in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
For this form see vol. 3, under Marin (8) S-H/F, p. 684.
Jewishness suggested based on the identification of the names as Jewish, but see vol. 3, under Marin S-H/F, p. 685, n. 1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the Golan, north east of the Sea of Galilee.
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.
In northern Jordan.
See above, n. 4.

state.note: Helkiah (8)’s descendent, Ossean of TranjordanF:– S: Epiphanius,PG41, 264E: Jew?D: 306-337

person.note: The suffix is unusual for this name, but I could think of no other.
In Greek – τῶν ̓Οσσηνῶν καλουμένῃ ἡς ἔτι λείψανα … ἐν τη͂ α̓τη͂ Ναβατίτιδι γη͂ (of the Ossenians, who are still left … in the land of the Nabateans).
In Panerion 20:4 Epiphanius claims that the Ossaeans are no longer Jews. Yet she is descended from a Jew, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.4, p. 30.
Epiphanius describes them as dating to the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1.1. On this sort of Semitic suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.3.7, p. 11.
See above, n. 3.
See above, n. 4
See above, n. 5.

state.note: Susanna (1)’s mother, married to a gentile

person.note: For this form see vol. 1, under Martha (1) S-H/F, p. 423.
In Greek – ἱερεὺς τῶν εἰδώλων … ̓νόματι ̓Αρτέμιος …Οὑτος ἔγημεν γυναῖκα ̓Ιουδαίαν , ̓νόματι Μάρθαν (a priest of idols … named Artemius … he married a Jewish wife, named Martha).
She is dated either to the days of Maximianus (293-305) or to the days of Maximinus (305-311), see Introduction 7.1.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this Semitic suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27.
In Judea, south of Bethlehem.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
See above, n. 10.
In Greek – ἐ(των)ν ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
In Transjordan.
The region was densely populated by non-Jews. Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.2.1.6.
See above, n. 15.
On the form מרתה see vol. 1, under Martha (6) S-H/F, p. 423. On the additional א as a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3, p. 13.
The inscription is dated to 379 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
So in the Pesaro (1511) Print. On this name see next note.
See Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 315-6.
Her father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

Although this tradition in BT is the only one in which she is mentioned, she is described as encountering a rabbi in the marketplace, which makes it likely that it took place in Palestine. There were very few Samaritans in Babylonia, and see Introduction 1.
In Aramaic – כותית היא (she is a Kuthian, i.e. the rabbinic term for Samaritan, see Introduction 6.1.1.1).
Was a contemporary of Ada (1) S-H/M in vol. 4, p. 326.
In a parallel tradition in yNaz 7:1, 56a she is mentioned as יהודיניי.
She is the sister of Judah (10) the Patriarch who was in office at the time of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Kibbutz in the south of Israel. Found in an apse of a synagogue.
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. This would read in Hebrew סול.
In Arabic – جارية.
She is described as a Samaritan’s slave, but she need not have been one herself, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.4.1, p. 30.
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.
Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1.1.
This is a composition which describes the martyrdom of saints.
She is the daughter of a pagan priest and a Jewish woman. The text describes her conversion to Christianity.
She is dated either to the days of Maximianus (293-305) or to the days of Maximinus (305-311), see Introduction 7.1.
For this form see vol. 3, under Susannah (5) S-H/F, p. 687.
In Greek – ζήσασα ἔτη να ́.
In Lebanon.

Jewishness suggested based on name and formula on grave (χρηστὴ καὶ ἄλυπε χαῖρε excellent one and who caused pain to none farewell), but both are inconclusive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52 and 6.10.3, p. 58.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
This is an unusual transliteration of this name, not recorded elsewhere. On the problems of transliterating this name into Greek see vol. 1, under Shelamzion S-H/F, pp. 426-9.

Both incomplete versions are found on the amulet, making the reading well nigh certain. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Shelamzion (2), p. 426.
Kibbutz in the north-western Negev.
This seems to be the same name with a vowel-consonant interchange, perhaps indicating another dialect, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp.12-3
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is perhaps dated so according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
For the vowel-consonant interchanges in this name, perhaps indicating another dialect, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp.12-3
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the parallel text in yShab 14:4, 14d, she is designated – ברתיה דדמיטינוס (daughter of Domitianus), but this is a “scribal correction,” see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 169.
In this text we are informed that Rabbi Yohanan (1) received medical treatment from her. Further on this text see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 167-72.

In the end of this text one rabbi suggests that she converted to Judaism, which may imply that she was no Jew to begin with. However, this is difficult, and see what I wrote in Silencing the Queen, 168-71.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. This would read in Hebrew תרנא.
See in vol. 4, under Dhakwān (1) A/M, pp. 273-4.
In Arabic – من اهل صفورية (of the folk of Sepphoris). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Described in the text as – يهودية (Jewess), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 27.
Was a contemporary of Muhammad, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.3.2, p. 42.

div.note: אמבוה means “crowd, escort” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 74). The form ’MBY is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 5).
The form ’MR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 75). The form ’MRY is recorded for males in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 5).
אמא/אימא means “mother” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 50). On family members as names see vol. Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. This name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 68-9).
This name probably means “mother of the Rabbi” or “mother of the Great One,” but no recorded parallels were found.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
זעירתא means “small, young, tender, lesser, little” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 407).

חליפא means “replacement, substitution” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469). The name חליפו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448. The form ḤLF is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 198). The form ḤLYPT is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 22). This is clearly an androgynous name, employed for both males and females see under Ḥalifa (3), (6), (8) and (22) S-H/M, and see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.2, p. 15; vol. 4, Introduction 2.6, pp. 16-7.

חרתא means “free woman” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 509). The name חרתו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 493. The form ḤRT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 182). The form ḤRT’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 23).
יאיתא/יאייתא/יאיותא means “beauty, grace” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 559).
יהודי means “Jew” in Hebrew/Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 566).
מחרישה means “plough” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 764). The name מחרשו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 624.
מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). Quite a few inscriptions document this name. Stark, PNPI, 37, argues that מרא/ה in Palmyra is feminine.
The form MRN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 542).
מרתא means “mistress” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). The name is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 695); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 97).
Name not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.

מתון means “slow, careful, considerate, patient” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 860). The name מתנו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 710. The form MTN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 527).

נהורא means “eye-sight” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 881). The form NHR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 601). NHR’ is recorded for females in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 39). It is recorded as a male name too, see under Nehorai S-H/M.
נתר means “natron, carbonate of soda,” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 946.
סול means “thorn, a wooden prick” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 964). The form SWL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 335).

שושנה in the Bible is the lily (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4). The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1118, and שושנת no. 1119). Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel (C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions[The Anchor Bible; New York 1977] 77-116).

The name שלמציון (“the peace of Zion,” or “the wholeness of Zion”) was not biblical. It was a new and popular name for women in the Second Temple period in Palestine. It went out of use soon after. See vol. 1, Introduction under Shelamzion S-H/F, p. 427, n. 1.

On this name as being female, see Rosenthal, Rabbi Hiyya, 308-9, n. 58 and see also Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 285-6. For the Nabatean שילת see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1124. The form ŠLWT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 356).
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
תרנאin Aramaic means “mast, yard,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1700. The form TRN is recorded for in Arabic for females, see Harding, ICPIANI, 132.
